snippet: “The Memory Show,” a musical, reflects the tensions of caring for someone with Alzheimer’s disease — and being someone with Alzheimer’s disease.

headline.main: Caregiver and Patient, Bound by Blood and Whining
headline.print_headline: Caregiver and Patient, Bound by Blood and Whining

snippet: Eight partners at Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz are proposing that company boards consider adopting a bylaw prohibiting shareholder activists from compensating director nominees.
abstract: Eight partners at Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz are proposing that company boards consider adopting a bylaw prohibiting shareholder activists from compensating director nominees.

headline.main: A Strong Response to Paying Board Nominees

snippet: If a deal for Waze is concluded, it would give Facebook the ability to better deliver tailored ads and content to its 1.1 billion users.
abstract: Facebook is in serious discussion to buy leading mobile navigation and map service Waze in deal that some say could exceed $1 billion; if concluded, sale would allow Facebook to better deliver locally tailored ads and content to its 1.1 billion users.

headline.main: Facebook Said to Be in Talks With Mobile Map Service
headline.print_headline: Facebook Is Reported To Be in Negotiations With Mobile Map Service

snippet: David Steinberg, chief of XL Marketing, says that entrepreneurs can learn a lot about people and understand them if they are more open and inquisitive.
abstract: Adam Bryant Corner Office column features Q&A with XL Marketing chief executive David Steinberg, who discusses his career and management technique.

headline.main: He’s No Longer the Loudest Guy in the Room
headline.print_headline: He’s No Longer The Loudest Guy In the Room

snippet: After a surprising five-day rally, the day’s economic data was mostly positive, although all of the major indexes were weak.
abstract: Stock market retreats from nominal highs as Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slips after five days of gains; some analysts express surprise that rally lasted so long despite lack of positive economic news.

headline.main: After 5 Days of Gains, Momentum Dwindles
headline.print_headline: After 5 Days of Gains, Momentum Dwindles

snippet: Belt-tightening and the declining value of the yen helped Sony earn $435 million for the year. The big Japanese company forecast higher net income for 2014.
abstract: Sony reports annual net profit of 43 billion yen, or $435 million, up from loss of 456.7 billion yen, or $4.6 billion, one year earlier; is Sony's first annual profit in five years, but company's future continues to hinge on turning around its unprofitable electronics business.

headline.main: Sony Posts Annual Profit for First Time in 5 Years
headline.print_headline: Sony Posts Annual Profit For First Time in 5 Years
